race.name: Ouray Gravel Grinder
race.tagline: Where gravel meets the sky - high-altitude suffering in Colorado's Switzerland

distances.name: Alpine Loop
distances.description: High elevation loop topping 12,000+ ft via Engineer and Cinnamon Passes

distances.name: Black Bear Pass
distances.description: Classic San Juan jeep road - most dangerous 4x4 road in Colorado

terrain.description: Extreme high-altitude San Juan Mountain passes on jeep roads, topping above 12,000 ft

typical.conditions: High altitude mountain weather, 72-81 thunderstorm days/year, monsoon season July-August, hypothermia risk

uniqueCharacteristics: Alpine Loop and Black Bear Pass routes

logistics.explanation: Remote location with Montrose airport 35 miles away and limited small-town services. Research reveals no specific 'Ouray Gravel Grinder' event exists - the area offers exceptional self-supported riding but requires 5+ days for altitude acclimation at 7,792 ft base elevation.

length.explanation: The 80-mile distance becomes substantially more challenging in the San Juan Mountains context. Routes like the Alpine Loop cover 65-80 miles but can take 6+ hours due to sustained grades above 10% and significant hike-a-bike sections on passes like Engineer and Cinnamon. Longer than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

technicality.explanation: San Juan Mountain routes feature grades exceeding 20% on bare rock sections. Imogene Pass is described as 'barely a road, a trail' with 'brutally steep and completely made of bare rock in certain sections.' Even 34x42 gearing is often insufficient. Among the most technical in gravel, on par with Badlands.

elevation.explanation: Starting at 7,792 ft and climbing through passes above 12,000 ft creates extreme elevation profiles. Imogene Pass tops out at 13,114 ft while Engineer Pass reaches 12,800 ft. The Alpine Loop alone gains over 3,300 ft through high-altitude terrain. Among the hilliest in gravel, comparable to Badlands.

climate.explanation: The San Juan Range experiences 72-81 thunderstorm days annually - Colorado's highest. Monsoon season brings afternoon storms that can shift from clear skies to hail within minutes. The golden rule: be below treeline by noon during storm season. Among the most weather-friendly events, easier than Badlands.

altitude.explanation: Power output drops 20-30% at these elevations, with sustainable watts falling to 70-80% of sea level capacity at 12,000+ ft passes. Even acclimatized riders experience significant performance degradation in the thin air above Ouray's 7,792 ft starting elevation. Among the highest-altitude events in gravel, on par with Badlands.

adventure.explanation: The San Juan Mountains offer bucket-list terrain through historic mining routes and 13,000+ ft peaks. Black Bear Pass is labeled 'most dangerous 4x4 road in Colorado' while routes traverse moon-like landscapes above treeline through some of America's most remote high-altitude gravel.

prestige.explanation: No organized 'Ouray Gravel Grinder' event exists despite the area's reputation. The closest major event is the Telluride Gravel Race 25 miles away, while the region attracts dedicated bikepacking communities through self-supported adventures rather than formal racing.

race_quality.explanation: Without an organized event, there's no race infrastructure to evaluate. Self-supported riding means no aid stations, course marking, or official support. Riders navigate independently through terrain that demands complete self-sufficiency in extreme conditions.

experience.explanation: RMWilson describes events in mountain terrain as offering 'beautiful scenery, breakfast included, inexpensive camping spots' as an 'all around great event.' The San Juan landscape creates lasting memories through postcard Colorado scenery and extreme high-altitude challenges.

community.explanation: The lack of an established standalone event limits community development. While the Silverton Project historically ran 'Ouray Week' from 2016-2018, it moved to Silverton for fresh routes, indicating limited sustained event community in Ouray proper.

field_depth.explanation: No organized competition means no competitive field to assess. While individual riders tackle the San Juan Mountain terrain through self-supported adventures, this represents exploratory riding rather than structured racing with measurable field depth. Thinner field than Back Forty Highlander.

value.explanation: Without entry fees (no organized event), the riding itself offers exceptional value. Outstanding terrain accessible to anyone who can get there and is prepared for the challenge. Hot springs recovery is a bonus.

expenses.explanation: Lodging runs $250-300/night at properties like Twin Peaks Lodge with natural hot springs. Montrose airport provides reasonable access at 35 miles, though the remote location requires extended stays for proper altitude acclimation, increasing total trip costs. More affordable than Crusher in the Tushar.

race.notes: No clearly documented recurring 'Ouray Gravel Grinder' event with fixed organization. Scoring reflects the self-supported gravel riding experience in the Ouray/San Juan region based on Alpine Loop, Black Bear Pass, and Imogene Pass routes. Course profile scores reflect the exceptional difficulty of the terrain; editorial scores reflect the lack of organized event infrastructure. For organized racing, consider nearby Telluride Gravel Race.

final_verdict.one_liner: The Ouray Gravel Grinder doesn't exist as an organized race, but the San Juan Mountains will humble your FTP and test your ability to push a bike up 13,000-foot passes.
final_verdict.should_you_race: You can't race what isn't there, but if you're drawn to self-supported suffering in Colorado's most brutal terrain, bring a mountain bike and your hiking legs. The Alpine Loop and Imogene Pass will have you walking more than riding above 12,000 feet, and afternoon thunderstorms don't negotiate with your Strava segment dreams. This is bikepacking country masquerading as a gravel destination.
final_verdict.alternatives: Hit the actual Telluride Gravel Race 25 miles away for organized pain with 10,000 feet of climbing, or SBT GRVL in Steamboat for high-altitude suffering with better logistics and real competition instead of just you versus gravity.

course_description.character: Ouray serves up 80 miles of high-altitude punishment across mining roads that were never meant for bicycles. You'll grind through San Juan valleys on County Road 23 before the real show beginsâ€”12,000-foot alpine passes where your 34x42 becomes a prayer. This isn't gravel racing, it's controlled mountaineering on two wheels.

suffering_zones.label: County Road Reality Check
suffering_zones.desc: Rolling ranch roads through Ridgway Valley give you false confidence before the climbing starts. Use this time to dial in nutrition because things get serious fast.

suffering_zones.label: Alpine Loop Entry
suffering_zones.desc: The road tilts skyward toward Engineer Pass and your easy spinning ends forever. Welcome to 4WD mining roads where 10% grades are considered gentle.

suffering_zones.label: Engineer Pass Summit
suffering_zones.desc: At 12,800 feet, your lungs find out what thin air actually means. The descent is loose rock and exposure that'll make you religious about tire pressure.

suffering_zones.label: Cinnamon Pass Finale
suffering_zones.desc: Just when your legs are cooked, another 12,600-foot pass appears. The babyhead rocks and moon dust surface will test whatever's left in your soul.

course_description.signature_challenge: Engineer and Cinnamon passes back-to-back above 12,000 feet, where even Tour de France climbers end up walking sections. The altitude turns your FTP into a cruel joke, and the loose rock surfaces make every pedal stroke a negotiation with gravity.

unsplash_photos.description: Close-up of fine grey sand texture
a red fire hydrant sitting on the side of a road
A pile of small, smooth, multi-colored pebbles.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
